prior_works.title: Comparator-Adaptive Φ-Regret
prior_works.role: Immediate predecessor establishing comparator-adaptive Φ-regret via sparsity measures
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present paper directly improves upon Lu et al. (2025) by achieving strictly better comparator-adaptive Φ-regret bounds and far simpler algorithms, replacing Lu et al.’s sparsity-based machinery with a prior-based approach over binary transformations.

prior_works.title: Kernelized Hedge
prior_works.role: Algorithmic building block for efficiently handling exponentially many comparators
prior_works.relationship_sentence: One of the paper’s concrete algorithms is constructed by combining multiple copies of the kernelized Hedge algorithm of Farina et al. (2022), enabling efficient aggregation over a vast family of binary transformations.

prior_works.title: Prediction, Learning, and Games
prior_works.role: Foundational source for Hedge with priors and prior-dependent regret
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The key idea of assigning a prior over comparators and obtaining regret that scales with the prior mass traces to the exponential-weights framework in this book, which the paper generalizes from experts to transformation comparators.

prior_works.title: From External to Internal Regret: Learning in Games with Transfer
prior_works.role: Core framework connecting action-transformations to internal/swap regret
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s Φ-regret setting and its specialization to internal/swap regret build on Blum–Mansour’s transfer-mapping viewpoint, which formalizes comparator transformations central to this work.

prior_works.title: Internal Regret in Online Portfolio Selection
prior_works.role: Seminal algorithms and analysis for internal/swap and generalized transformation regret
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work underpins the Φ-regret framework and efficient reductions from transformation-based regret to implementable learning rules, informing the design and analysis in the present paper.

prior_works.title: A Simple Adaptive Procedure Leading to Correlated Equilibrium
prior_works.role: Motivating application link between (swap/Φ-)regret and game-theoretic equilibria
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing that vanishing swap regret implies convergence to correlated equilibria, this work motivates the paper’s applications to games using improved Φ-regret guarantees.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper advances the general Φ-regret paradigm, where performance is measured against action-transformations, by delivering improved comparator-adaptive bounds with simpler algorithms. Its immediate antecedent is Lu et al. (2025), which introduced comparator-adaptivity via a sparsity-based complexity of the transformation; the present work replaces that machinery with a principled prior over binary transformations, yielding tighter, prior-dependent guarantees and cleaner algorithms. This prior-centric move is rooted in the exponential-weights literature (Cesa-Bianchi and Lugosi, 2006), where initializing Hedge with nonuniform priors leads to regret scaling with the comparator’s prior mass; the authors lift this idea from experts to transformation comparators, identifying a specific prior that suffices for binary mappings.

The transformation viewpoint itself traces to classical internal/swap regret frameworks (Blum and Mansour, 2007; Stoltz and Lugosi, 2005), which formalized competing against mappings of actions and provided reductions and algorithms that the current work generalizes and unifies under Φ-regret. To make the approach computationally viable over exponentially many transformations, the paper leverages kernelized Hedge (Farina et al., 2022), combining multiple copies to efficiently implement the prior-weighted aggregation over binary transformations. Finally, the game-theoretic significance (Hart and Mas-Colell, 2000) underlies the applications: improved and simpler Φ-regret algorithms directly strengthen convergence guarantees to correlated (and related) equilibria. Together, these threads—comparator adaptivity, prior-based Hedge, transformation regret, and kernelized efficiency—culminate in sharper bounds and streamlined methods for Φ-regret and its game-theoretic applications.
